comments.comment: What is the measurement range of the device

We believe that Doze will be able to measure within the two-digit range of mSv/h. According to the supplier, the GM tube can be used in environments of up to 300 mSv/h. However, the overall performance of Doze will depend on its final PCB design and programming. Some minor optimizations are still ongoing.
In the near future, I plan to replace the GM tube with a signal generator to check the limitations of the PCB and program.
So is it TSA compliant for travel in an aircraft

A Geiger counter, which is used to detect and measure ionizing radiation, is generally not prohibited by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) for carry-on or checked baggage. The Doze with a 400mAh battery should generally be safe to bring through TSA security. However, it's always a good idea to check the latest TSA guidelines and your airline's policies before traveling.

Is there an "accumulated dose" feature in firmware? IMHO it is the most usable feature for this kind of EDC gadget.

Doze measures the accumulated dose from the moment you switch it on (or when you reset the timer via a button press). If the dose or dose rate exceeds the defined limit, an alarm occurs. Additionally, Doze measures the peak rate and records the time it was measured, enabling the user to recall where it happened. Another feature is that Doze measures the average dose rate. We find this particularly helpful when measuring small differences in radiation between various objects or environments.

As you do not provide device schematic, is there a chance that I can physically damage circuit board when modifying firmware, e.g. by accidentally increasing high voltage generator output level? Is high voltage generator managed by Attiny or is it an independent circuit?

We do not see a way to damage the PCB board by changing the firmware. The high voltage unit is a separate circuit and can only be switched on and off by the controller. We will add detailed comments to the firmware to guide programmers through the code.

Why did you choose a GM tube over a scintillation crystal?

Thank you for supporting our project. The use of a GM tube has been central to our vision for Doze from the very beginning, which is why we didn't decide for alternative solutions. This choice stems from personal reasons: we all learned about the GM tube's measuring principle in school, we're fans of novels and games like Metro, and we loved the idea of featuring the GM tube as a visible design element in Doze.

Thank you for your question! We appreciate your curiosity.

Regarding the one-year battery timeframe: Doze enters sleep mode in the Lifeguard configuration (display off, controller in sleep mode). In this state, Doze consumes only a few microamperes (Î¼A) in the double-digit range, which means that a 400 mAh battery can last more than one year. Despite being in sleep mode, Doze continues to measure. Whenever a particle is detected, it wakes up, logs the measurement, and then returns to sleep mode.

Doze can measure the radiation levels of food, though not as accurately as specialized devices. This is because it also accounts for the ambient radiation in your surroundings. To obtain precise radiation levels in food, complex measurements are required to determine whether -and to what extent- a food item is contaminated with radioactivity. First, food samples must be prepared in a specific manner and protected from external influences. Then, measurements are conducted using specialized devices that are far more accurate and sensitive than a Geiger counter. Such devices are typically found only in specialized facilities.

Either way, your thoughtful answers are excellent and I look forward to the success of this project.
The ability to customize the USB connection is great too.

The Geiger tube draws power from a charged capacitor, which is recharged periodically for a fraction of a second. The required power is negligible in normal radiation environments. Despite the charging process, the charging module is completely switched off. Most of the time, Doze is in sleep mode and only wakes up when a particle is detected.

Q: Can you implement a serial console or any other interface? I would like to connect Doze to Home Assistant. Would it be possible?

we think this is a very good idea. Unfortunately, Doze does not have this feature. But there is a way to allow Doze to do serial communication. It could be a good project for our Backer community with Doze in their hands:

We decided to use the bootloader Micronucleus for Doze which allows users to upload programs simply via USB. With this feature, a serial interface via USB (more precise V-USB) cannot be implemented in the program anymore. However, users will have the chance to upload own programs directly over the ISP interface, that means without the Micronucleus bootloader. The PCB design of Doze offers free connection pads that can be directly connected to an ISP programmer (e.g. USBTinyISP). With this method, it should be possible to implement serial communication via USB in the program.
I hope my answer helps you. We are glad to know if the community has other ideas.
